awd_titl_txt: QLCI-CG: Institute for Chiral-Quantum Materials Interfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
The Quantum Leap Challenge Institutes (QLCI) program is part of the Quantum Leap, one of the research Big Ideas promoted by the National Science Foundation. This award is a QLCI Conceptualization Grant, which supports activities to build capacity among teams planning for the large-scale, interdisciplinary Challenge Institute projects that aim to advance the frontiers of quantum information science and engineering. Research at these Institutes will span the focus areas of quantum computation, quantum communication, quantum simulation, and/or quantum sensing. The Institutes are expected to foster multidisciplinary approaches to specific scientific, technological, and workforce development goals in these fields. 

This Conceptualization Grant will develop well-formulated plans for a future Challenge Institute proposal focused on novel science and technology of the interface of two-dimensional quantum materials and chiral molecules.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
●      A schematic roadmap for molecular QIS was developed based on the following research directions and practical applications

○      Fundamental challenges and opportunities

○      Molecular sensors

○      Molecular Information storage

○      Quantum information

○      Controlling coherence

○      Controlling information transduction

○      Interplay of photonics and spin polarization

○      Metamaterials

●      Keck Foundation Grant that evolved as a distinct collaboration proposal on quantum biology.

●      The initial conceptualization of a Center for Quantum Biomolecular Information Sciences

 

Principal publications resulting from initiative activities include:

The following publications were either direct outcomes of initiative activities or strongly influenced by its activities and participants.  The first publication is a review that resulted from the first two workshops conducted in 2020.  The second paper was strongly influenced by initiative PI Mujica and two other ICQMI participants and became an important review on the status of the theory of the CISS effect, an essential ingredient of all the effort in chiral interfaces, spin polarization and the design of Molecular Quantum Interconnects.  The third publication is the result of the third workshop that focused on roadmap development.  It is scheduled to be submitted in December 2023. 

(1)  “A Chirality-Based Quantum Leap” (Aiello, et al, ACS Nano 2022, 16, 4, 4989–5035, 2022; https://doi.org/10.1021/acsnano.1c01347) was published and has been cited 32+ times in subsequent publications, and viewed over 14,820+ times. It was selected as an ACS Nano “Editors Choice”.

(2)  “Theory of Chirality Induced Spin Selectivity: Progress and Challenges,” (Elvers, et al, Advanced Materials, 2022, https://doi.org/10.1002/adma.202106629) has been cited by 61 subsequent publications in the field of CISS.

(3)  “Hybrid Systems for Molecular Quantum Information Science,” (Mujica, et al, ACS Nano Review, submitted December 2023)
